<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_io_block_write:
```c
int metal_io_block_write(struct metal_io_region *io, unsigned long offset,
	       const void *restrict src, int len)
{
	unsigned char *ptr = metal_io_virt(io, offset);
	const unsigned char *source = src;
	int retlen;

	if (!ptr)
		return -ERANGE;
	if ((offset + len) > io->size)
		len = io->size - offset;
	retlen = len;
	if (io->ops.block_write) {
		retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
	} else {
		while ( len && (
			((uintptr_t)ptr % sizeof(int)) ||
			((uintptr_t)source % sizeof(int)))) {
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
			ptr++;
			source++;
			len--;
		}
		for (; len >= (int)sizeof(int); ptr += sizeof(int),
					source += sizeof(int),
					len -= sizeof(int))
			*(unsigned int *)ptr = *(const unsigned int *)source;
		for (; len != 0; ptr++, source++, len--)
			*(unsigned char *)ptr =
				*(const unsigned char *)source;
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_seq_cst);
	}
	return retlen;
}
```
</target_code>

suspicious_frags:
retlen = (*io->ops.block_write)(
			io, offset, src, memory_order_seq_cst, len);
explanation: Only actual function-call sites can create direct or indirect recursion that would violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2. The three call expressions above are the only function calls in the provided function body and thus are the only places that could possibly lead to metal_io_block_write calling itself (directly or indirectly). Other code fragments in the function — pointer arithmetic (ptr++, source++), casts and dereferences (e.g. *(unsigned char *)ptr, *(const unsigned int *)source), loop constructs (while, for), comparisons and assignments, the bounds check and the return statement — are not function calls and therefore cannot introduce recursion. The constant/macro memory_order_seq_cst and simple arithmetic like (offset + len) or % sizeof(int) are not function calls either. Consequently those non-call constructs do not need investigation for Rule 17.2 compliance.
